clinical_study.brief_title: Hand Grip Strength as a Marker of Frailty in Surgical Patients
clinical_study.official_title: Hand Grip Strength as a Marker of Frailty in Surgical Patients

brief_summary.textblock: This study aims to assess if grip strength can be used as a single, objective surrogate of frailty assessment in the surgical population.

detailed_description.textblock: Frailty is associated with worse outcomes. Current screening surveys are cumbersome, most containing multiple components. For frail patients particularly, it can be difficult to ascertain all the information requested. There is a need for a simple, one step, objective screening measure of frailty. There is some evidence in the medicine patients that grip strength may be related to frailty, but no such information is available for surgical patients.

primary_outcome.measure: linear regression of grip strength to frailty survey score
primary_outcome.time_frame: 10 minutes at the time of admission
primary_outcome.description: Their frailty survey and grip strength scores will also be recorded for analysis. We will analyze the data by linear regression of grip strength to frailty survey score.

arm_group.description: General surgery patient admitted to the Section of General Surgery, Trauma, and Surgical Critical Care who are over 60.

intervention.intervention_name: Obtain grip strength from a standardized gripometer
intervention.description: Obtain grip strength from a standardized gripometer, 3 times on each hand

study_pop.textblock: General surgery patients admitted to the Section of General Surgery, Trauma, and Surgical Critical Care who are over the age of 60.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- General surgery patient admitted to the Section of General Surgery, Trauma, and Surgical Critical Care
- Age >60
Exclusion Criteria:
- Pregnancy
- Untreated or metastatic malignancy
- Prisoners
